ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

OUTPATIENT CLINICS
(Adequacy of)


    1. Mr Ang Nam Piau asked the Minister for Health whether the number of outpatient clinics is adequate and the clinics are suitably sited to serve the increasing and shifting population, and, if not, what measures his Ministry is taking in the matter.

     The Minister for Health (Dr Toh Chin Chye): Mr Speaker, Sir, at present, there are 26 outpatient dispensaries (OPDs) and 30 maternal and child health (MCH) clinics in Singapore. The OPDs offer general curative services to the public while the MCH clinics provide preventive health care to pregnant women, infants and pre-school children, and at the same time offer family planning services.

    With the shift of population to Housing and Development Board new towns, the Ministry plans to build a polyclinic where there is a concentration of 100,000 people or more. These polyclinics will provide comprehensive health care which includes curative,

Column: 430

preventive, dental and home nursing services. Within this year, three such polyclinics in Bedok, Clementi and Bukit Merah new towns will start operations, and in 1980 a polyclinic in Ang Mo Kio new town is expected to start functioning. The Ministry of Health proposes to establish polyclinics wherever HDB new towns are planned.

    Because of the population shift, some of the existing OPDs and MCH clinics which are experiencing low attendances have been closed. Where facilities are available, OPDs and MCH clinics which are now functioning in separate buildings will be integrated under one roof for the greater convenience of patients.

MINIMUM WAGE LEVEL


    2. Mr Ang Nam Piau asked the Minister for Labour whether the Government intends to impose a minimum wage level for Singapore workers.

     The Minister for Labour (Mr Ong Pang Boon): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Government does not intend to impose a minimum wage level.

    A minimum wage policy is unnecessary in the Republic. Such a policy is normally introduced to ensure that workers have a

Column: 431

sufficient wage to meet basic needs and to protect those in weak bargaining positions. As hon. Members know, our workers enjoy a good standard of living and their basic needs are more than met. Besides, the State provides them with good subsidised social services like housing, education and health services.

    Furthermore, our expanding economy is experiencing full employment and occasionally even labour shortages. There is, therefore, no difficulty in securing jobs with reasonable wages, Those who feel that they are being exploited can easily find alternative employment. The need for a minimum wage is also made less relevant by the higher wage and higher productivity policies we have just adopted to restructure our economy.

    Market forces should be allowed to determine the wages of workers to ensure the most efficient allocation of labour. In a full employment and labour shortage situation, this will not affect adversely workers' bargaining positions or their ability to secure decent wages.

    It is Government's policy, therefore, to work towards the free play of market forces in the determination of wages. In its press statement on the NWC recommendations for 1979, my Ministry has said that the NWC must take greater account of market forces in the formulation of wage increase guidelines. The NWC shall work towards a situation where employers and unions can be left to negotiate wage increases entirely on their own. The imposition of a minimum wage level for Singapore workers would be contrary to this policy.

ENTRY PERMITS FOR MALAYSIANS WITH
SINGAPORE CITIZEN FAMILIES


    3. Mr Teo Chong Tee asked the Minister for Home Affairs whether he will grant an entry permit to a Malaysian citizen or a Malaysian permanent resident if the

Column: 432

members of his family are either Singapore citizens or Singapore permanent residents.

     The Minister for Home Affairs (Mr Chua Sian Chin): Mr Speaker, Sir, the grant of an entry permit for permanent residence in Singapore is governed by the provisions of the Immigration (Prohibition of Entry) Order, 1973. It is not a right but a privilege, and each case is processed and decided upon on its merits. Family roots are only one of the factors taken into consideration when assessing applications for permanent residence. Much will depend on whether an applicant has a skill or qualification which is needed in Singapore and can contribute or has contributed to the well-being of the country. Generally, applications from professionals or skilled persons for permanent residence are considered favourably. Male applicants who are of National Service age are also considered favourably provided they sign up for regular service in the SAF.

     Mr Teo Chong Tee (Changi): Sir, may I ask the Minister whether special consideration will be given in the case of a single aged parent, all of whose children are either Singapore citizens or permanent residents?

     Mr Chua Sian Chin: Sir, as I have said, each case will have to be treated on its own merits, There are a number of factors to be considered. If a sponsor has an aged parent, one of the factors we will have to consider is whether, after having granted the aged parent an entry permit, the aged parent is likely to become a liability to the State. The other factor to consider is whether the aged parent has got relatives or persons who can look after him. Sometimes we also do give consideration on grounds of compassion.

     Mr Teo Chong Tee: Sir, may I further ask the Minister whether he could provide figures to show the number of such applications for entry permits which have been rejected, approved and pending during the last two years?

Column: 433



     Mr Chua Sian Chin: Sir, I do not have the figures of applications approved and rejected for the last two years. I happen to have figures for the period from January 1977 to August 1979, which is more than the two-year period. For the period January 1977 to August 1979, 11,870 applications for permanent residence were approved. This compares very favourably with 4,021 applications which were rejected during the same period. In other words, 11,870 applications were approved as compared with 4,021 applications rejected.

PUBLIC ACCOUNTS COMMITTEE
(Implementation of recommendations)


    4. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for Finance what measures his Ministry contemplates to take in regard to the observations and recommendations of the Public Accounts Committee contained in Paper Parl. 4 of 1979.

     The Minister for Finance (Mr Hon Sui Sen): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Report of the Public Accounts Committee is presently being studied by my Ministry. The Committee's observations and recommendations will be implemented, where practicable.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting (Punggol): Sir, while it is encouraging to hear from the Minister for Finance that his Ministry is studying the observations and recommendations of the Public Accounts Committee (Paper Parl. 4 of 1979), could he also enlighten the House as to when his Ministry will put the recommendations of the PAC into practice?

     Mr Hon Sui Sen: Sir, the Report and recommendations of the Public Accounts Committee have always been considered seriously by my Ministry. Where necessary, we enter into correspondence either with the Auditor-General or with the Public Accounts Committee if the replies, which we furnish through the Auditor-General, appear to be unsatisfactory to the Committee. There are, of course, other recommendations which are capable of immediate implementation, and in such cases we would certainly take action immediately.

ANG MO KIO NEW TOWN
(Bus services)


    5. Mr Yeo Toon Chia asked the Minister for Communications and Acting Minister for Culture when the bus terminus at Ang Mo Kio New Town will be completed and what is the number of bus services to be provided; and, in view of the increasing population in Ang Mo Kio, whether he has any immediate plan to improve the existing bus services.

     The Minister for Communications and Acting Minister for Culture (Mr Ong Teng Cheong): Mr Speaker, Sir, the new bus terminus at Ang Mo Kio town centre was completed in April this year.

    At present there are 14 bus services in Ang Mo Kio, of which seven operate from the new terminus. The remaining seven services which are now operating from a temporary terminus at Avenue 6 will be shifted to the new terminus before the end of this year.

    Next month, SBS will introduce two more services in Ang Mo Kio; one to Bedok and the other to the New Bridge Road Corridor. Four more buses will also be added to the existing services to meet the increasing demand.

PREFERENTIAL ADDITIONAL
REGISTRATION FEE
(Position beyond 1979)


    6. Mr Hwang Soo Jin asked the Minister for Communications and Acting Minister for Culture whether the present

Column: 435

system of granting Preferential Additional Registration Fee (PAR F) values to scrap cars will continue beyond 1979; and, if not, what changes are contemplated in regard to both the licensing of new cars and the continued maintenance of cars over 10 years old.

     Mr Ong Teng Cheong: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Preferential Additional Registration Fee (PARF) to encourage the early replacement of old cars will continue beyond 1979. The condition that cars must not be more than 10 years old to be eligible for PARF after 1st January, 1981, will remain unchanged. It was first announced by the Ministry of Finance in December, 1975.

    PARF should be continued as it has helped to control the growth of private cars by taking off old cars from the road whenever a new one is registered. Our figures show that in 1978, out of 16,531 new private cars registered, 15,438 or 93% were registered under PARF. There was a net increase of 3,342 cars or 2.8% growth in the private car population. Had there been no PARF, this increase would have been much higher.

    At present, cars over 10 years old are subject to a surcharge on an increasing scale up to a maximum of 50% of the road tax. This surcharge was imposed to discourage the use of old, inefficient and unsafe cars on the road. I announced in Parliament early last year that we are studying the possibility of introducing compulsory car inspections to ensure the road-worthiness of vehicles. Details are now being worked out by the Registry of Vehicles, When it is introduced, the surcharge on old cars will be abolished.

     Mr Hwang Soo Jin (Jalan Kayu): Sir, I would just like to take the opportunity to ask the Hon. Minister whether he will agree to extend the PARF value to stolen cars.

     Mr Ong Teng Cheong: Mr Speaker, Sir, we have not come across cases of this nature, and no application has been made officially so far. When such an application is made, we will give it due consideration.

LORONG LODEH
(Pedestrian crossing facilities)


    8. Mr Teo Chong Tee asked the Minister for National Development why there is no provision for pedestrian crossing facilities for the daily use of approximately thirty families at Lorong Lodeh to safely and conveniently cross the Pan-island Expressway where it cuts across Lorong Lodeh.

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Pan-island Expressway at Lorong Lodeh is now under construction and will not be completed until early 1981. There is at present a temporary access for residents to cross the construction site to Lorong Tebera or Jalan Somapah Timor opposite. When the Expressway is opened, residents will be able to cross the Expressway by an alternative access route at the Expressway's junction with Upper Changi Road. The Public Works Department will monitor this pedestrian traffic and, if the volume justifies it, consideration will be given to the construction of a pedestrian bridge across the Expressway at Lorong Lodeh.

CHANGI CONSTITUENCY
(Five-year development plans)


    9. Mr Teo Chong Tee asked the Minister for National Development what development plans his Ministry has for Changi constituency in the next five years, other than the Changi Airport project.

Column: 437



     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, there are several development plans for Changi constituency in the next five years.

    The Jurong Town Corporation will develop the new Changi South Industrial Estate for clean industries. The Estate covers some 170 hectares and will be planned in a park-like setting.

    The Parks and Recreation Department will develop the East Coast Park Extension and the coastal strip abutting the Changi Airport. The area involved is about 113 hectares. Basic park amenities such as cycle tracks, benches and refreshment facilities will be provided.

    Singapore Airlines will be developing a 2.8 hectare Sports Complex near Fairy Point. The Complex will provide a comprehensive range of sporting and recreational facilities.

    Several road projects have been planned to serve the Constituency. The portion of the Pan-island Expressway in the Changi constituency will be completed within the next two to three years. The north-south arterial road linking the Pan-Island Expressway with the East Coast Parkway will be completed within the next five years. The New Upper Changi Road from Bedok Road to Tampines Road now under construction will be completed next year. A coastal road next to the Airport running towards Changi Point will be completed within the next three years.

     Mr Teo Chong Tee: Sir, may I ask the Hon. Minister whether there are any plans to build Housing Board flats, although the number of residents in Changi is getting less and less each day?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, with the development of the new Changi Airport we have exercised considerable restraint in the construction of HDB flats in the area because most parts of the Constituency fall within the noise zone. It is just like the present Paya Lebar Airport where there is virtually no construction of flats in the Paya Lebar constituency.

CHUA CHU KANG CONSTITUENCY
(Establishment of modern pig farms)


    10. Mr Tang See Chim: To ask the Minister for National Development whether the Government has any plans for the establishment of large modern pig farms with pollution control equipment in the Chua Chu Kang constituency and, if so, when those plans will be implemented and where the farms will be located.

     Mr Speaker: Mr Tang.

     Mr Ho Kah Leong (Jurong): Question No. 10, Sir.

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, pig farming is a highly pollutive activity. With limited land resources we cannot continue to sustain small inefficient pig farms spread out haphazardly all over Singapore. Besides under-utilizing our scarce land resources, such farms because of their pollutive nature will sterilise large tracts of land which can be used for industrial, commercial or residential development.

    The Government has, therefore, decided that in order to control pollution, all future pig farming activities should be concentrated in a relatively isolated agricultural area in the north-west corner of Lim Chu Kang. Large modern commercial farms rearing a minimum of 5,000 pigs each on an intensive basis will be set up. Efficient farmers and other entrepreneurs can apply for land for this purpose.

    The Government will provide waste treatment facilities for the pollutive discharge from pig farms at Lim Chu Kang. A levy of $10 per pig slaughtered in Singapore will soon be introduced to enable waste pollution facilities to be set up. It is expected that this levy will increase the retail price of pork by only 15 cents per kati. In return, Singaporeans will be able to continue enjoying local fresh pork at reasonable price.

    Land is being acquired at Lim Chu Kang and development work will commence in the near future.

Column: 439



    With the development of Lim Chu Kang as a pig farming area, no pig rearing will in future be allowed elsewhere in Singapore. As a first step, the Government will phase out all pig rearing from the catchment areas and river basins in Singapore over the next two years. Thereafter, pig rearing in other areas will be phased out.

    Existing intensive pig farms at Punggol will be permitted to remain for the next 10 years. Pig farms at Jalan Kayu which have adversely affected the amenity of nearby residential areas will be phased out earlier, In the phasing-out process, the Primary Production Department will give every assistance to pig farmers who wish to convert to other non-pollutive types of farming.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting: Mr Speaker, Sir, if I may be permitted to refer the Hon. Minister to Hansard, dated 16th February, 1977 [Vol. 36, cols. 192-3], a photocopy of which was extended to him by me just now. In that Hansard, I asked a question on pig farming in Punggol, and a reply was given by the hon. Member for River Valley who was then the Senior Minister of State for National Development. He stated, and I quote:

    'The very fact that we have given leases of 30 years [i.e. to Punggol pig farmers] we can even speculate that it is very likely that pig farming will be there for 15 to 30 years.'

    Sir, if I heard the Minister correctly just now, he said that the Punggol pig farms would be phased out in 10 years. If the statement in the Hansard is correct, there seems to have been a change of policy. Would the Minister then consider enabling the pig farmers in Punggol to continue their pig farming activities for the duration of the lease that they have been given, i.e. between 15 and 30 years? If that is not possible, would the Minister consider paying enhanced rates of compensation for the loss of future earnings, bearing in mind that these pig farmers have been resettled at least three to four times over? I do not know how many times more they will have to be resettled.

Column: 440



     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, just now I mentioned that pig farms in Punggol will be permitted to remain for another 10 years. The former Senior Minister of State for National Development mentioned in February 1977 that the pig farms were likely to remain in Punggol for another 15 years. About 2 1/2 years have elapsed. If the pig farmers remain there for another 10 years, that means 12 1/2 years, and the phasing-out process will perhaps take one or two years. The statement that the pig farms will remain in Punggol for another 15 years is, in fact, correct and the Government has not changed its policy.

SELETAR FARMWAYS
(Resettlement of pig farmers)


    11. Mr Hwang Soo Jin asked the Minister for National Development (a) whether there is any plan to resettle pig farmers in Seletar Farmways in the Lim Chu Kang area; (b) if so, when this is expected to take place; and (c) whether he will give an assurance that, if resettlement for any important reason becomes necessary, enhanced rate of compensation will be paid especially to those who have already been inconvenienced once before and that every endeavour will be made to minimise hardship and disruption in the production.

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, there have been complaints of intermittent malodour against the pig farms in the Seletar Farmway area from residents in the nearby residential estate at Seletar. Owing to their proximity to residential estates, these farms will have to be phased out. However, they will not be required to do so immediately.

    The programme for phasing out is being worked out, taking into account the development of Lim Chu Kang as an intensive pig farming area and clearance of other pig farms in the catchment areas. Every endeavour will be made to minimise hardship and disruption. Under the new resettlement policy, enhanced rates of compensation will be paid to these farmers.

     Mr Hwang Soo Jin: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Hon. Minister seems to give the impression that there has been an oversight in converting the Seletar Farmways into a pig farm area, and therefore the farmers will now have to be resettled again. I am just wondering whether the same mistake will be made in the case of Lim Chu Kang, when in due course the farmers there will again have to be resettled.

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, Lim Chu Kang has been chosen as a pig farming area because it is far away from any residential estate, Moreover, owing to its remote location, it does not lend itself favourably to development as a residential estate.

    12. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for National Development, in view of the inadequate facilities at the Kangkar Fish Market, when his Ministry will build another fish market.

BEAUTIFICATION OF SINGAPORE


    13. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for National Development whether his Ministry has any plans to beautify the Republic by planting more flowering plants, e.g. in the city, Housing and Development Board estates and other suitable places.

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, since April, 1978, my Ministry has implemented an intensive programme to beautify the Republic by planting trees and shrubs along roads, in public parks, housing estates and other places. As part of this programme, some 50,000 flowering trees and 20,000 free-flowering shrubs have been planted. During the next 18 months, the Parks and

Column: 442

Recreation Department will plant 75,000 trees and 600,000 shrubs throughout the Island. Of these, 60% will be of the flowering variety.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting: Mr Speaker, Sir, apart from the planting of free-flowering shrubs and trees, will the Hon. Minister give consideration to landscaping these areas to add to the beauty of the area?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Sir, the answer is yes. The planting of trees and flowers always goes hand-in-hand with the landscaping of the area.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting: Sir, I am not too sure that they always go hand-in-hand. I myself am not a town planner or a landscaper. But I am sure hon. Members will agree with me that along the roads we see more trees, more greenery, than colour, if at all there is any colour. If one takes a drive to the City, he does not see much colour apart from the buildings and the trees. Could the Minister look into this aspect of landscaping suitable places to add beauty and colour, apart from the greenery?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am in full agreement with the Member for Punggol, but in our beautification campaign, we usually start with the planting of trees. A tree is a large plant with a crown of leaves and branches. This is especially so with the instant trees which grow very fast. So generally they give the impression of a mass of greenery, This, in fact, is what we want. We want to put the greenery first, and the next step is to introduce colour.

     Dr Ong Leong Boon (Kim Seng): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am sure the Minister is aware that Singapore is largely a fruit-importing country and, therefore, will he consider planting fruit trees in addition to just trees and flowering plants?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, in fact, this has been carried out. We have been planting fruit trees in army camps and in schools. That is the first step. Subsequently, when our children have acquired a good sense of leaving the fruits alone, we can then

Column: 443

most probably plant fruit trees along the streets.

     Mr Hwang Soo Jin: Mr Speaker, Sir, can the Hon. Minister please assure the House that no fruit trees will be planted along pedestrian walks? I do not fancy being hit on the head by fruits!

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, I think we can leave it to the experts in the Parks and Recreation Department to decide on the proper site for the planting of fruit trees. I am sure they will take this into consideration when they plant the fruit trees.

     The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Labour (Mr Fong Sip Chee): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    Honourable Members will recall that the Factories Act, 1973, was amended in March

Column: 444
